11430451.trustfund:
TF022179-PHRD 2-AGRICULTURAL FINANCE SYSTEM,TF027967-SECONDMENT FROM HOECHST
            SCHERING AGREVO,TF029549-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL SUPPORT
            SERVICES PROJ.(BANK-EXEC.),TF030444-SWITZERLAND CTF - FY04
            (AZERBAIJAN, KYRGYZ REPUBLIC, TAJIKISTAN, TURKME,TF033196-UZBEKISTAN - AGRICULTURAL
            SUPPORT SERVICES PROJECT,TF034760-UZBEKISTAN - COTTON IMPROVEMENT PROJECT,TF035918-UZBEKISTAN - PREPARATION OF AGSAL,TF036016-ECA REGION - WATER AND
            AGRICULTURE (ARMENIA, UZBEKISTAN),TF036259-UZBEKISTAN - COTTON SUB-SECTOR
            IMPROVEMENT AND AGRICULTURE,TF037072-UZBEKISTAN - AG. ENT. RESTR.
            PROG. I,TF039060-TURKMENISTAN - SOCIAL
            ASSESSMENT - AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT,TF039900-UZBEKISTAN - RESP AND ARMENIA ARSP,TF053128-PHRD-UZBEKISTAN: RURAL
            ENTERPRISE SUPPORT PROJECT
11430451.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Enterprise Support
            Project for Uzbekistan were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: extension to neighboring districts and a broader
            selection of options for investment categories and financial
            products will have aided a wider reach of beneficiaries and
            would have promoted diversification of lending. Future
            diversification will help lenders in developing a more
            balanced lending portfolio and enable them to develop a
            wider range of skills in assessing types of risk. For
            borrowers, access to new financial products and an expanded
            set of investments would enable them to diversify their
            businesses, manage risks more efficiently and enter into new
            profitable activities. There was no need to provide two
            credit schemes within one project. One overall credit scheme
            should suffice, but with differing credit guidelines and
            loan appraisal criteria, depending upon the size of the
            loan. With a standalone credit line, it is difficult to
            encourage the participation of local banks. The reducing
            margin on cotton cultivation brings the risk that farmers
            may lose interest in cotton production, further decreasing
            investment in inputs and hence reducing yields. This call
            for corrective measures, including more significant
            increases in prices paid to farmers and continued efforts to
            increase further crop yields through investing in Irrigation
            and Drainage (I&D) improvements, advisory services,
            improved fertilization, crop rotation, and crop protection
            as cotton yields remain low by international standards.

            SERVICES PROJ.(BANK-EXEC.),TF030444-SWITZERLAND CTF - FY04
            (AZERBAIJAN, KYRGYZ REPUBLIC, TAJIKISTAN, TURKME,TF053128-PHRD-UZBEKISTAN: RURAL
            ENTERPRISE SUPPORT PROJECT,TF022179-PHRD 2-AGRICULTURAL FINANCE SYSTEM
5083650.majtheme: Rule of law,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Enterprise Support Project for
            Uzbekistan aims to increase the profitability and
            sustainability of agriculture through the privatization and
            restructuring of farming and associated agribusiness
            activities. There are four main project components. The
            first supports providers of business farm advisory services
            in the rural sector, so that they can better assist
            participants in the restructuring process become familiar
            with policies, laws, regulations, and procedures underlying
            the restructuring process, as well as business planning
            activities, agro-technical information (traditional farm
            extension), and perhaps market information. The second
            component focuses on rehabilitating irrigation and drainage
            systems. The investments will be chosen by water users
            groups to be formed under the project. The third component
            provides lending for both working capital and investment
            expenditures by private farms and rural businesses. To be
            eligible for loans, borrowers must have completed legal
            procedures concerning privatization and restructuring (in
            the case of farms) or be private or privatized nonfarm
            enterprises. The fourth component supports credits to
            establish well-equipped private agro-service centers for
            machinery services and supply of agricultural inputs, which
            would create competition with the existing state-owned
            enteprises in the machinery services and input markets.
